p.strong: Boston Prep’s building is closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year. Our top priority remains the heath and safety of our community.

div.p: We will be regularly maintaining the information below to ensure students and families have access to the most up-to-date information.

div.p: ** We are continuing to offer meal service daily during the scheduled April vacation week, 4/20 - 4/24.**

We are offering food service for any children in Boston every Monday - Friday during this extended closure. When picking up, students can gather both lunch and breakfast. In order to maintain social distancing, we will use a staggered approach to food pick up.

li.p: Last name A – D 11:00 - 11:30 AM
Last name E – K 11:30AM - 12:00 PM
Last name L – Q 12:00 - 12:30 PM
Last name R – Z 12:30 - 1:00 PM

div.p: Additionally, students are welcome to use any food distribution site in the City of Boston. You do not need to come to Boston Prep and can instead go to sites closer to your home. A full list and map of Boston meal sites can be accessed on the City of Boston's website.

p.em: Check out these additional resources in our community! If you are in need of any sort of assistance, there are many resources available to help during this time.

li.p: COVID-19 in Boston: The latest local guidelines and resources. You can also get texts from the City of Boston about COVID-19.
Text BOSCOVID to 99411 to sign up in English.
Text BOSEspanol to 99411 to sign up in Spanish
Text BOSKreyol to 99411 to sign up in Haitian Kreyol.
The Outbreak of COVID-19 in MA (MA Department of Public Health). You can also dial 2-1-1 for information and statewide resources related to COVID-19.
COVID-19 Across the US (CDC)
Many news sources, including The New York Times and State House News Service, are currently offering free access to enable the public to stay informed.

span.strong: Understanding COVID-19 & How to Stay Safe

li.p: What To Do If You Are Sick (CDC)
If you believe you may have COVID-19, call your primary care provider or the Mayor’s hotline at 617-534-5050 (toll-free: 1-800-847-0710).
Find a nearby testing site. Testing is free regardless of insurance or immigration status. Always call ahead
Our school nurse, Malorie Golafaie, is also available to support you and can be reached at mgolafaie@bostonprep.org.
Know the Symptoms of COVID-19 (CDC)
How to Prevent Getting Sick (CDC)
MassHealth Connector - Open Enrollment through April 25th for those who are uninsured.

div.p:
Access to Food
Boston has many food sites available for families, the elderly, and the general public. If you need assistance identifying other ways to access food for your family, the agencies below are ready and able to help.

p.a: Greater Boston Food Bank Agency Locator

p.strong: If you’ve lost a job or are experiencing reduced hours:

li.p: File for unemployment assistance online. Have questions, or want to learn more? Attend a Department of Unemployment Assistance (DUA) Town Hall. (Also available in Spanish.)

The new Pandemic Unemployment Assistance (PUA) program provides up to 39 weeks of unemployment benefits for those who are unable to work because of COVID-19 but are not eligible for regular or extended unemployment benefits. That includes self-employed workers, independent contractors, gig economy workers, and those with limited work history.
If you do not qualify for unemployment benefits, you may qualify for Disaster Unemployment Assistance.

United Way has established the COVID-19 Family Support Fund to provide cash assistance to working families affected by the public health emergency. Dial 2-1-1 and ask for the United Way Family Support Fund to learn more about how to get support.
Union Capital Boston is providing Visa gift cards to those in urgent need in the Greater Boston area.
Emergency financial assistance for undocumented individuals impacted by COVID-19 can be requested from the Betancourt Macias Family Scholarship Foundation and the MassUndocuFund.
Rental Relief: The City of Boston created a Rental Relief Fund for tenants who fall behind on rent because of the crisis.

div.p: Communities across the Commonwealth are springing into action to help our neighbors. We all have something to offer, and we all have something we need. Share what you can offer to your local community and what you need.

span.strong: Mental Health Resources for Students and Families

p.strong: How to maintain your own mental health and that of your family

li.p: Our Health & Counseling team has compiled a tremendous array of resources in the Wellness Library.
COVID-19 Information and Resources (National Alliance on Mental Illness)
Helping Children Cope With Changes Resulting From COVID-19 (National Association of School Psychologists)
Supporting Families During COVID-19 (Child Mind Institute) - Includes daily Facebook Live video chats for parents and guardians.
Managing Stress During This Outbreak (CDC)

Need counseling support? If your student would benefit from counseling, please reach out to their advisor. Our Health & Counseling team members are continuing to provide counseling support during our closure. Family members can also access the following resources:
If you or someone in your family is in crisis, call 1-800-981-4357 for guidance. The Boston Emergency Services Team provides crisis evaluation and treatment services.
If you are experiencing domestic abuse, contact the National Domestic Violence Hotline online or by calling 1-800-799-7233 or texting LOVEIS to 22522.
If you are struggling with thoughts of self-harm or suicide, contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline online or by calling 1-800-273-8255.
Text HOME to 741741 to be connected to a live, trained Crisis Counselor on the Crisis Text Line. Volunteer Crisis Counselors provide 24/7 support at your fingertips.
If you just need someone to talk to, 7 Cups offers free 24/7 connection to caring listeners who can offer emotional support.
For a long-term counseling referral, contact the William James INTERFACE Referral Service online or at 888-244-6843.
Emergency child care programs are being made available to emergency workers on a limited basis who have no other option for childcare during this public health crisis.
American Red Cross Babysitter’s Handbook - A great resource for students who are now caring for younger siblings.
Comcast is offering 60 days of free Internet Essentials to new low-income customers .
Verizon announced two months of waived Internet and voice service charges for current Lifeline customers. The company also has new, affordable Internet options for low-income households.

Starry is offering free service until the end of May to all current Starry Connect subscribers and anyone who signs up for Starry Connect before the end of May. You must live in a building that is currently served by the Starry Connect program.
Xfinity is offering free access to their 1.5 million hotspots. To find your nearest hotspot, enter your zip code.
Charter Communications is offering 60 days of free Spectrum broadband and WiFi access to new customers whose household includes a K-12 student or a college student.
CorePower is offering many free new yoga classes each week.
If you’re looking for variety, check out Classpass, which is offering free, unlimited access to over 2,000 video workouts.

div.p: This crisis, more than ever, reminds us of the importance of having full access to government resources during times of need. Ensuring everyone fills out the Census helps us get the maximum amount of dollars and representation in Congress. Fill out the census here. It takes 5-10 minutes. To learn more about why the census is important check out the City of Boston's site.
